blog.name: frost-iron
blog.title: Frost Iron
blog.description:
Volatile, self-obsessed, doesn't play well with others, and very sexually frustrated.

Welcome to Frost Iron! A blog dedicated to all things Loki/Tony or Tony/Loki if you prefer. If you have any questions or want to submit anything just hit up our ask or submit box. Note: this is a blog for the characters and no RPS(F) will be posted.

Blog owner

title: Fic rec
body:
Hello, I want to share with everyone my lucky finding of the weekend : the fantastic fic Tea with the Hatter, by the very talented theorytale, author of some quality frostiron fic like From a seed or The Saga of Hug fortress.

Tea with the Hatter is basically a groundhog day fic, with lots of magic an science combined (Tony gets magic!), a well thought plot, good characterization, and some snark. Everything I love ! WIP, but only one more chapter to go, apparently

summary: OOo drabbles. What about Tony having appendicitis and the only person he can call is Steve
question: OOo drabbles. What about Tony having appendicitis and the only person he can call is Steve
answer:
“Hey, Steve?”  Tony breathes in and out slowly, trying not to blow into the phone.

“No annoying nickname today?” 

The reception’s bad, but Tony hears a thumping sound in the background.  “Please tell me you’re on a treadmill, and not doing…”  He would’ve said it, just to annoy Steve, but the sharp pain in Tony’s stomach flares, and he has to bite his lip to keep from crying out.

“I was done running anyway.”  There’s a beep and the thumping stops.  “What’s up?”

“Promise you won’t freak out,” Tony says.  

“Why would I freak out?”

“Mm, just promise you won’t.”  Tony swallows nausea as he waits for Steve to reply.

“Ok?  Is it a mission or what?” Steve’s voice goes echoey.  Tony imagines him stepping into a dingy locker room.

“Yeah, I guess.  Think of it as a mission.”

“That’s not giving me a lot of confidence,” Steve says.

“Well, I would’ve called literally anyone else, but the tower’s empty, and Happy’s taking Pepper to the airport, and you know how bad traffic is this time of the afternoon–” Tony’s stomach clenches, and he has to lunge for the kitchen sink before he dry heaves.

“Tony?  You ok?”  

“Uh.”  Tony tears off a paper towel to wipe his mouth.  “This is usually where I’d lie and say ‘yes,’ but under these circumstances, I’m gonna have to go with no.  Can you drive me to the ER?”

There’s a beat of silence.  Then the sound of a locker door slamming shut.  Tony hears Steve take a breath, but all he says is, “On my way.”

blog.title: There is nothing glorious about me.

summary: Wisdom? :D Knowledge? peace? Whichever one you want!
question: Wisdom? :D Knowledge? peace? Whichever one you want!
answer:
I’m falling asleep as we speak, so honestly, no guarantees here. I went with “Wisdom”, but maybe with a twist (I guess).

“You know, Tony, I really don’t get why you and Cap fight constantly,” Rhodey mused.

Tony turned away from the screen he had been working on for the past twenty minutes and glared at Rhodey. Unfortunately for him, Rhodey had become immune to Tony’s glares a long time ago, and simply raised his eyebrows at him.

“Seriously dude, it’s like you enjoy fighting,” Rhodey continued, taking one of the screwdrivers from the cluttered desk in front of him, turning it around in his hand. “Only you aren’t seven-year-olds pulling each other’s pigtails. You’re superheroes.”

Tony huffed lightly, but didn’t comment either on the pigtail pulling nor on the mention of superheroes.

“Steven Grant Rogers is full of opinions,” he said instead, turning back towards the screen and typing in another line of code. “It’s rather difficult finding something he doesn’t feel strongly about.”

Rhodey observed Tony in the blue glow of the screen for another minute, just as he had been doing before he started with his musings. Tony, as always, looked tired, but Rhodey could also tell that he was on a roll. Something had taken hold of that peabrain and needed to get put on paper… figuratively. There was no getting him out of the workshop unless it was an emergency, or he was finally finished.

“I’m sure it also has nothing to do with the decidedly non-platonic feelings that are involved as far as Steven Grant Rogers is concerned.”

Tony winced. Actually, physically winced in a manner that spoke more than words ever could, if Tony would ever use words. There was no doubt that Rhodey had hit bullseye, and there was no way Tony could claim plausible deniability. Not that Rhodey would let him get away with that kind of bullshit even if he tried.

After a few moments of Tony gathering himself, he replied stiffly, “Whatever emotions may or may not be involved, nothing has happened, nothing will ever happen, and it does not impact our relationship or our relationships with the Avengers in any way.”

“I’m sure,” Rhodey replied, putting the first screwdriver away and taking another one lying on the desk.

Interesting, he thought to himself. That’s a design I don’t recognise. Alien?

“I’m serious here, Rhodey,” Tony said, sounding decidedly off-put. Rhodey looked up and noticed the pronounced wrinkle between Tony’s eyebrows.

“Yeah, me too, sugarpuff,” he replied. “That’s why we’re having this conversation.”

“You mean, you are having this conversation,” Tony corrected, but he sounded slightly mollified. ‘Sugarpuff’ usually did the trick.

“That’s fine with me, just let me have my say, and I’ll be on my way,” Rhodey said, lifting his hands in a pacifying gesture.

Tony sighed. Then he tuned fully away from the screen, giving Rhodey his full attention for the first time since they had started to talk.

“Fine.”

“You two are terrible, you know,” Rhodey said immediately, not bothering with any formalities. “I get that it’s this weird flirting thing you do or something, but I also think that some members of the Avengers get a little jumpy around you two because they can’t get used to the constant arguing. So, can you maybe do something about that?”

“I wish I could tell you that I’ve figured out how to deal with Steve in a more peaceful manner, but unfortunately, I haven’t,” Tony said, rubbing the bridge of his nose. “He’s one of the co-founders of the Avengers, he’s my friend, and I really appreciate him as a person, but sometimes, I just want to strangle him.”

“Maybe you should try that sometime,” Rhodey suggested. “It might help. Or maybe you’re just a kinky bastard. Can I take that with me, by the way? I really dig the design and I want to take a closer look at it.”

He waved the alien screwdriver in front of Tony’s nose.

“Sure, take it,” Tony said. “But honestly, I’d also prefer a more peaceful solution. Despite anything you say, I don’t actually enjoy fighting all the time.”

“I know,” Rhodey said, pocketing the screwdriver. (He might have a use for that one.) “And neither does he. And neither does the rest. Which is why we are having this conversation.”

“So what do you suggest, o wise one?” Tony teased, his mouth turning up into a smile. “A heart to heart? Are you going to lock us into a cupboard until we’ve made up? A get-along shirt?”

“You’re an adult, Tones,” Rhodey interrupted before the list went on. “You should figure it out yourself. Between yourselves. You’re good at figuring out stuff. And if you really get stuck somewhere, you come to the rest of us and we will try to help.”

“No plan of action,” Tony said, his grin widening. “Candy cane, you astonish me.”

“I’m your friend, not your therapist,” Rhodey said, shrugging. “Now go do that thinkie thing you’re so good at.”

Tony looked like he was planning to shoot something back, but then he paused, and just released a long breath.

“You’re right,” he admitted. “Of course you are. Time to do that thinkie thing.”

“Thank you,” Rhodey said. And in a way, he was. Tony might rarely actually agree with his advice, but he would never refuse to listen to it. That was the best he could be hoping for at the moment, he guessed. “I’ll leave you to your brain, then.”

“See you later,” Tony murmured, his attention already shifting back towards the blue screen in front of him.

“Later,” Rhodey replied, getting up and moving towards the entrance of the workshop. His mission was accomplished, at least for now.

When he had almost reached the door, Tony called out to him once more. Rhodey turned back.

“Yes?”

“Tell Carol, next time she wants something she can come personally.”

“And me losing a chance to chew you out?” Rhodey asked. “You wish.”

Tony did not reply, but the blue shine of the screen in front of him did indeed nicely frame his answering smile.

Rhodey observed Tony in the blue glow of the screen for another minute, just as he had been doing before he started with his musings. Tony, as always, looked tired, but Rhodey could also tell that he was on a roll. Something had taken hold of that peabrain and needed to get put on paper… figuratively. There was no getting him out of the workshop unless it was an emergency, or he was finally finished.

“I’m sure it also has nothing to do with the decidedly non-platonic feelings that are involved as far as Steven Grant Rogers is concerned.”

Tony winced. Actually, physically winced in a manner that spoke more than words ever could, if Tony would ever use words. There was no doubt that Rhodey had hit bullseye, and there was no way Tony could claim plausible deniability. Not that Rhodey would let him get away with that kind of bullshit even if he tried.

After a few moments of Tony gathering himself, he replied stiffly, “Whatever emotions may or may not be involved, nothing has happened, nothing will ever happen, and it does not impact our relationship or our relationships with the Avengers in any way.”

“I’m sure,” Rhodey replied, putting the first screwdriver away and taking another one lying on the desk.

Interesting, he thought to himself. That’s a design I don’t recognise. Alien?

“I’m serious here, Rhodey,” Tony said, sounding decidedly off-put. Rhodey looked up and noticed the pronounced wrinkle between Tony’s eyebrows.

“Yeah, me too, sugarpuff,” he replied. “That’s why we’re having this conversation.”

“You mean, you are having this conversation,” Tony corrected, but he sounded slightly mollified. ‘Sugarpuff’ usually did the trick.

“That’s fine with me, just let me have my say, and I’ll be on my way,” Rhodey said, lifting his hands in a pacifying gesture.

Tony sighed. Then he tuned fully away from the screen, giving Rhodey his full attention for the first time since they had started to talk.

“Fine.”

“You two are terrible, you know,” Rhodey said immediately, not bothering with any formalities. “I get that it’s this weird flirting thing you do or something, but I also think that some members of the Avengers get a little jumpy around you two because they can’t get used to the constant arguing. So, can you maybe do something about that?”

“I wish I could tell you that I’ve figured out how to deal with Steve in a more peaceful manner, but unfortunately, I haven’t,” Tony said, rubbing the bridge of his nose. “He’s one of the co-founders of the Avengers, he’s my friend, and I really appreciate him as a person, but sometimes, I just want to strangle him.”

“Maybe you should try that sometime,” Rhodey suggested. “It might help. Or maybe you’re just a kinky bastard. Can I take that with me, by the way? I really dig the design and I want to take a closer look at it.”

He waved the alien screwdriver in front of Tony’s nose.

“Sure, take it,” Tony said. “But honestly, I’d also prefer a more peaceful solution. Despite anything you say, I don’t actually enjoy fighting all the time.”

“I know,” Rhodey said, pocketing the screwdriver. (He might have a use for that one.) “And neither does he. And neither does the rest. Which is why we are having this conversation.”

“So what do you suggest, o wise one?” Tony teased, his mouth turning up into a smile. “A heart to heart? Are you going to lock us into a cupboard until we’ve made up? A get-along shirt?”

“You’re an adult, Tones,” Rhodey interrupted before the list went on. “You should figure it out yourself. Between yourselves. You’re good at figuring out stuff. And if you really get stuck somewhere, you come to the rest of us and we will try to help.”

“No plan of action,” Tony said, his grin widening. “Candy cane, you astonish me.”

“I’m your friend, not your therapist,” Rhodey said, shrugging. “Now go do that thinkie thing you’re so good at.”

Tony looked like he was planning to shoot something back, but then he paused, and just released a long breath.

“You’re right,” he admitted. “Of course you are. Time to do that thinkie thing.”

“Thank you,” Rhodey said. And in a way, he was. Tony might rarely actually agree with his advice, but he would never refuse to listen to it. That was the best he could be hoping for at the moment, he guessed. “I’ll leave you to your brain, then.”

“See you later,” Tony murmured, his attention already shifting back towards the blue screen in front of him.

“Later,” Rhodey replied, getting up and moving towards the entrance of the workshop. His mission was accomplished, at least for now.

When he had almost reached the door, Tony called out to him once more. Rhodey turned back.

“Yes?”

“Tell Carol, next time she wants something she can come personally.”

“And me losing a chance to chew you out?” Rhodey asked. “You wish.”

Tony did not reply, but the blue shine of the screen in front of him did indeed nicely frame his answering smile.
trail.content_abstract:
I’m falling asleep as we speak, so honestly, no guarantees here. I went with “Wisdom”, but maybe with a twist (I guess).

“You know, Tony, I really don’t get why you and Cap fight constantly,” Rhodey mused.

Tony turned away from the screen he had been working on for the past twenty minutes and glared at Rhodey. Unfortunately for him, Rhodey had become immune to Tony’s glares a long time ago, and simply raised his eyebrows at him.

“Seriously dude, it’s like you enjoy fighting,” Rhodey continued, taking one of the screwdrivers from the cluttered desk in front of him, turning it around in his hand. “Only you aren’t seven-year-olds pulling each other’s pigtails. You’re superheroes.”

Tony huffed lightly, but didn’t comment either on the pigtail pulling nor on the mention of superheroes.

“Steven Grant Rogers is full of opinions,” he said instead, turning back towards the screen and typing in another line of code. “It’s rather difficult finding something he doesn’t feel strongly about.”

summary: Prompt #1: Peter gets up for a late night snack and tries not to wake up the Avengers.
body:
Prompt #1: Peter gets up for a late night snack and tries not to wake up the Avengers.

Peter tip-toes to the kitchen at the Avenger’s facility.

He walks past all of their rooms and sees that they’re all sound asleep and lets out a relieved sigh.

“Thank God no one’s awake, we have a huge mission tomorrow.” Peter says to himself.

He opens the fridge and looks at all the food that he can eat and his mouth begins to water. 

Tony sneaks up behind him and gently places his hands on Peter’s shoulders.

“Do we, now?” 

Peter jumps across the room and shoots webs everywhere. Then, he shoots his webs directly at the dark figure standing in front of the fridge and hangs them on the wall. 

“AAAAH! Mr. Stark, you scared me!”, Peter yells. 

Tony is absolutely covered in webs and his feet are off the ground. 

“I wasn’t expecting to get hung off the wall like this is if I’m being honest.” Tony says. “Get this stuff off of me right n…”

Before he can finish the sentence the Avengers show up to the kitchen completely geared up and ready to fight. They all start laughing once they realize that it was just Tony and Peter.

“And to think that we thought there was somebody attacking us.” Natasha says while laughing. 

“Mr. Stark thought it was a good idea to scare me while I was looking for something to eat!” Peter replies. 

Tony is still hanging from the wall, there’s no expression on his face. Natasha hasn’t stopped laughing and the rest of them are wondering how this happened. 

“Can one of you please explain what happened?” Thor asks. 

“Well, I woke up because I heard someone walking to the kitchen, so I got up and followed them. When I saw it was Peter, I thought it’d be a good idea to scare him, y’know as a joke.” Tony explains while trying to loosen the grip of the webs.

Peter begins talking, “And then I jumped across the room and shot my webs everywhere and then hung Mr. Stark on the wall. I didn’t know it was him I thought someone broke into our kitchen.” 

“Get me off this wall now, Peter.” Tony demands. “You have 5 seconds to get me off this wall and go to your room.” 

Peter runs over and immediately takes the webs off. Tony falls to the ground with a thud. The Avengers start laughing as Peter runs to his room as fast as he can. 

“You better not leave that room until it’s time for the mission, young man!” Tony shouts while getting off the floor. 

“I’m sorry, Mr. Stark!” Peter yells from down the hall. 

“We all better go to sleep. We have a big day tomorrow.” Steve says, still laughing. 

Everyone goes back to their rooms thinking about the odd events that had just happened. Some of them giggle to themselves while walking back.

“Mr. Stark thought it was a good idea to scare me while I was looking for something to eat!” Peter replies. 

Tony is still hanging from the wall, there’s no expression on his face. Natasha hasn’t stopped laughing and the rest of them are wondering how this happened. 

“Can one of you please explain what happened?” Thor asks. 

“Well, I woke up because I heard someone walking to the kitchen, so I got up and followed them. When I saw it was Peter, I thought it’d be a good idea to scare him, y’know as a joke.” Tony explains while trying to loosen the grip of the webs.

Peter begins talking, “And then I jumped across the room and shot my webs everywhere and then hung Mr. Stark on the wall. I didn’t know it was him I thought someone broke into our kitchen.” 

“Get me off this wall now, Peter.” Tony demands. “You have 5 seconds to get me off this wall and go to your room.” 

Peter runs over and immediately takes the webs off. Tony falls to the ground with a thud. The Avengers start laughing as Peter runs to his room as fast as he can. 

“You better not leave that room until it’s time for the mission, young man!” Tony shouts while getting off the floor. 

“I’m sorry, Mr. Stark!” Peter yells from down the hall. 

“We all better go to sleep. We have a big day tomorrow.” Steve says, still laughing. 

Everyone goes back to their rooms thinking about the odd events that had just happened. Some of them giggle to themselves while walking back.

Peter tip-toes to the kitchen at the Avenger’s facility.

He walks past all of their rooms and sees that they’re all sound asleep and lets out a relieved sigh.

“Thank God no one’s awake, we have a huge mission tomorrow.” Peter says to himself.

He opens the fridge and looks at all the food that he can eat and his mouth begins to water. 

Tony sneaks up behind him and gently places his hands on Peter’s shoulders.

“Do we, now?” 

Peter jumps across the room and shoots webs everywhere. Then, he shoots his webs directly at the dark figure standing in front of the fridge and hangs them on the wall. 

“AAAAH! Mr. Stark, you scared me!”, Peter yells. 

Tony is absolutely covered in webs and his feet are off the ground. 

“I wasn’t expecting to get hung off the wall like this is if I’m being honest.” Tony says. “Get this stuff off of me right n…”

Before he can finish the sentence the Avengers show up to the kitchen completely geared up and ready to fight. They all start laughing once they realize that it was just Tony and Peter.

title: Chimaera
body:
read it on the AO3 at https://ift.tt/2PFeiVN

by Anonymous

The upshot is that the tower is pretty much empty, especially since Mr. Stark only occasionally leaves his lab for food or a change of clothes. He even sleeps in there, Peter is pretty sure. So Mr. Stark doesn’t seem to notice or care when Peter starts staying in one of the spare bedrooms in the old Avengers tower.

It’s sort of his room anyway, not in any official capacity but it’s the one he always stayed in after a mission if it was too late at night or he was too bloodied to go back home without freaking May out, which is something he doesn’t like to think about anymore.

Peter feels lost after the battle on Titan.

Sort of an AU (but not really), set post-Infinity War.

title: Love in Emerald
body:
read it on the AO3 at https://ift.tt/2NkYRk3

by Ultimate_Fandom_Queen

All Harry Potter ever wanted was a loving family. Unfortunately, as a 14 year old orphan being raised by his abusive aunt and uncle, that dream seemed far from his reach.

Meanwhile, all Bruce Banner ever wanted was a family of his own. Unfortunately, it seemed that because of a certain green friend, that dream would remain only a dream forever.

That is, until a box of letters belonging to his father reveals a flurry of secrets that could change the two men’s lives forever. Will they for the familial bond they’re blood dictates, or will the hardships of life be too much for them to overcome?

A story of finding a family, finding love, and finding moments of happiness in even the worst lives.
